p: In the Americas, CHIKV, which is an alphavirus, emerged for the first time at the end of 2013, and has infected over one million individuals since then ( 5). ZIKV is a flavivirus that emerged in the Americas in 2015 and 2016. An estimated 80% of acute ZIKV infections are asymptomatic, and the remaining 20% ​​clinically resemble CHIKV and DENV infection, including with symptoms of fever, rash, headache, and arthralgia ( 5- 7). Neurological complications, including Guillain–Barré syndrome, have also been reported after ZIKV infection ( 8, 9). Importantly, ZIKV infection during pregnancy is associated with severe teratogenic effects, including microcephaly ( 8- 11).
